content.div:
Was M.I.A.'s Super Bowl gesture her way of wishing the 111.3 million viewers at home "World Peace?" Yeah, probably not -- but it's been nearly a week since the "Bad Girls" MC played the halftime show with Madonna, and she's yet to comment.

Madonna, however, had some words today on the topic -- albeit belated ones. Chatting on Ryan Seacrest's radio show, Madonna said she definitely didn't engineer that bit of (minor) controversy.

Look: Madge has exerted complete and total control over her image, her music, her gladiatorial army of man-servants -- time itself! What can she say? Sometimes a bratty English rapper weasels into her blindspot.

"I was really surprised. I didn't know anything about it. I wasn't happy about it," Madonna told Seacrest of M.I.A.'s flipped bird.

"I understand it's punk rock and everything, but to me there was such a feeling of love and good energy and positivity, it seemed negative. It's such a teenager...irrelevant thing to do," she continued. "What was the point? It was just out of place."

On that note, let's get back on topic and revisit Madonna's most important talking point for the next few weeks: her new album! The Queen of Pop shared some (vague) details about upcoming disc MDNA, due March 26. It has "a lot of up-tempo [music], but I also have three ballads which I haven't done in a while."

So, basically, it's a Madonna album.

Still, she cleared up one tantalizing detail that began circulating this week: will Britney Spears appear on album track "Girls Gone Wild?"

Madonna, who told Seacrest she's preparing to shoot a video for the track, revealed that the rumours are false. "No, it's just little, ol' me," Madonna said of the song. "She can come on stage and perform with me."

Presuming she promises to behave herself, anyway.

leahc@dose.ca
